name: Steppe Lizard
description: A slender species with olive to brownish coloration and colorful spots on its dorsal side. The currently kept subspecies, E. a. uzbekistanica, has dark-edged, round spots arranged in regular transverse rows.
spread_note: Asia and Europe, from Romania to Mongolia
image_alt: Steppe lizard, photo: Prague Zoo archive
proportions: Length up to 20 cm, with the tail accounting for 50%; weight 20–26 g
reproduction: Females lay up to 12 eggs in one or two clutches annually, depending on size and geographic range of the subspecies; hatchlings emerge after over 2 months.
attractions: In sandy-soiled areas, it digs deep burrows; in steppes, it uses other animals’ burrows or natural crevices.
breeding: Since 2006, Prague Zoo has kept the subspecies E. a. deseri, and since 2011, E. a. uzbekistanica, both bred regularly.
